awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2020 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Justin D. Lanier is " Mapping Class Groups and Complex Dynamics." The host institution for the fellowship is University of Chicago and the sponsoring scientist is Danny Calegari .

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The PI's research has been driven by questions about surfaces and their self-maps. These questions range across a number of mathematical fields: algebra, dynamics, geometry, topology, and combinatorics.

The three research directions in the PI's project proposal were: (1) generating sets and homomorphisms of mapping class groups; (2) topological polynomials and complex dynamics; and (3) big mapping class groups and complex dynamics. The PI completed five research projects during the fellowship period: one each about mapping class group homomorphisms and topological polynomials and three about big mapping class groups.

With Lei Chen, the PI classified homomorphisms from mapping class groups to other groups by using arguments involving finite subgroups, with the target groups for the homomorphisms as other mapping class groups and homeomorphism groups of spheres.

With Rebecca R. Winarski, the PI solved an infinite family of twisted polynomial problems that are cubic generalizations of Hubbard’s twisted rabbit problem.

With Marissa Loving, the PI showed that every infinite-type surface with fi­ni­te-invariance index 1 and no nondisplaceable compact subsurfaces fails to have a good graph of curves.

With Nicholas G. Vlamis, the PI wrote two papers. The first paper classifies the connected orientable 2-manifolds whose mapping class groups have a dense conjugacy class (i.e. have the Rokhlin property). The second paper classifies the 2-manifolds whose homeomorphism groups have the virtual Rokhlin property and also establishes the analogous result for mapping class groups of 2-manifolds.

The mentorship the PI received from faculty and the experience of the research environment at the University of Chicago was formative in shaping the PI's research goals and agenda. During the fellowship period, the PI taught four undergraduate courses at the university, mentored several PhD and undergraduate students in reading projects, and contributed to the research environment by organizing seminars.

During the fellowship period, the PI made contributions to several service and outreach efforts to broaden participation in mathematics. The PI co-organized the SUBgroups program, which organizes online peer support groups for incoming math graduate students across universities. The PI co-organized the American Mathematical Society's paraDIGMS initiative, which helped to build a community of practice for math graduate program leaders in their work to foster graduate programs that serve the needs of all students, especially those belonging to groups that historically have been excluded from research mathematics. The PI organized "21st century mathematics", an online professional development program for K-12 teachers where participants encounter works of contemporary mathematics and connect these with their classroom practice. Finally, the PI led outreach sessions for middle school students with the Math Circles of Chicago.


Last Modified: 03/07/2025
Modified by: Justin Dale Lanier
